{{DISPLAYTITLE:Armament of the ''Iowa''-class battleship}} [[Image:Uss wisconsin bb.jpg|thumb|right|{{USS|Wisconsin|BB-64|6}}, photographed at sea in her 1980s configuration.]] [[Image:USS Missouri at Hungman.jpg|thumb|right|USS Missouri fires her 16-inch guns]]
The '''armament of the {{sclass-|Iowa|battleship|1}}s''' underwent a massive development since the first ''Iowa''-class ship was laid down in June 1940. Owing to the continual development of the weaponry aboard these battleships they remain the most heavily armed gunships the United States has ever put to sea. In their World War II configuration, each of the ''Iowa''-class battleships had a main [[artillery battery|battery]] of {{convert|16|in|mm|0|adj=on}} guns that could hit targets nearly 20 statute miles (32 km) away with a variety of [[artillery]] shells designed for anti-ship or bombardment work. The secondary battery of {{convert|5|in|mm|0|adj=on}} guns could hit targets nearly 9 statute miles (14 km) away with solid projectiles or proximity fuzed shells, and were equally adept in an anti-aircraft role and for damaging smaller ships. Each of the four battleships carried a wide array of 20 mm and 40 mm [[Anti-aircraft warfare|anti-aircraft guns]] for defense against enemy aircraft.
When reactivated and modernized in the 1980s each battleship retained the original battery of nine {{convert|16|in|mm|0|adj=on}} guns, but the secondary battery on each battleship was reduced from ten twin-gun mounts and twenty guns to six twin-gun mounts with 12 guns to allow for the installation of two platforms for the Tomahawk missiles. Each battleship also received four Harpoon missile magazines, [[Phalanx CIWS|Phalanx]] anti-aircraft/anti-missile [[Gatling gun]] systems, and [[electronic warfare]] suites. When required (duty in the Persian Gulf in particular) up to twelve single mount [[M2 Browning]] 50 caliber machine guns and four 35 mm [[Bushmaster Firearms International|Bushmaster]] cannon were installed to provide close range defense against small surface craft.
==Main battery==
===Turrets=== [[File:Uss iowa bb-61 pr.jpg|thumb|left|{{USS|Iowa|BB-61|6}} fires a full broadside of nine 16 inch (406 mm)/50-caliber and six 5-inch (127 mm)/38-caliber guns during a target exercise. There are concussion effects on the water surface, and the 16-inch (406 mm) gun barrels are in varying degrees of recoil.]]
The primary armament of an ''Iowa''-class battleship consisted of nine [[Breech-loading weapon|breech-loading]] [[16 inch (406 mm)/50 caliber Mark 7 naval gun|16 inch (406 mm)/50-caliber Mark 7 naval guns]],<ref>Originally the armament was to be nine 16"/50 (406 mm) Mark 2 Naval Guns intended for the canceled [[South Dakota-class battleship (1920)|''South Dakota''-class battleships]]; however, a miscommunication between the design bureaus resulted in the ''Iowa'' class being equipped with the Mark 7 Naval Guns instead. DiGiulian, Tony. [http://www.navweaps.com/Weapons/WNUS_16-50_mk7.htm United States of America 16"/50 (40.6 cm) Mark 7]. navweaps.com Retrieved on 2007-03-25.</ref> which were housed in three 3-[[gun turret]]s: two forward and one aft in a configuration known as "2-A-1". The guns were 66 feet (20 m) long (50 times their {{convert|16|in|mm|adj=on}} bore, or 50 calibers, from [[breechface]] to [[muzzle (firearm)|muzzle]]).<ref name="FAQ I">{{cite web|title = USS Missouri (BB-63) Frequently Asked Questions |work= USS Missouri (BB-63) Frequently Asked Questions | url = http://www.factplace.com/mightymo.htm#Weps | publisher = FactPlace.com |author= Ben M. Schorr |accessdate=2006-12-16|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060531135341/http://www.factplace.com/mightymo.htm#Weps|archivedate=2006-05-31 }}</ref>About 43 feet (13 m) protruded from the gun house. Each gun weighed about 239,000 pounds (108 000 kg) without the breech, or 267,900 pounds with the breech.<ref name="Mark7">{{cite web |url=http://www.navweaps.com/Weapons/WNUS_16-50_mk7.htm |title=United States of America 16"/50 (40.6 cm) Mark 7 |accessdate=2007-02-25 |date=November 2006 |author=DiGiulian, Tony |publisher=navweaps.com| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070205233558/http://www.navweaps.com/Weapons/WNUS_16-50_mk7.htm| archivedate= 5 February 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>For comparison, the [[Space Shuttle]], when fully loaded, weighs about 240,000 pounds, so each battleship gun is roughly the weight of a space shuttle. Schorr, Ben M. [https://web.archive.org/web/20060531135341/http://www.factplace.com/mightymo.htm#Weps USS Missouri Frequently Asked Questions]. factplace.com Retrieved on 2007-03-25.</ref>They fired projectiles weighing from {{convert|1900|to|2700|lb}} at a [[muzzle velocity]] of 2,690 ft/s (820 m/s)(1834.1 mph) to a maximum range of {{convert|42345|yd}} ({{convert|42345|yd|mi|2|disp=output only}}) using an [[Armor-piercing shot and shell|armor-piercing]] shell.<ref name="Mark7"/>
Each gun rested within an armored turret, but only the top of the turret protruded above the main deck. The turret extended either four decks (Turrets 1 and 3) or five decks (Turret 2) down. The lower spaces contained the equipment required to rotate the turret and to elevate the guns attached to each turret. At the bottom of the turret were rooms which were used for handling the projectiles and storing the powder bags used to fire them. All of the compartments within the turrets were separated by flameproof bulkheads to prevent any flame or lethal gas from spreading throughout the turret.<ref name="youtube">{{YouTube|0OmOQs0ziSU|United States Navy Training Film 9321c: The 16"50 Gun & Turret ("Sea Power for Security")}}</ref>Each turret required a crew of 77—94 men to operate.<ref name="Mark7"/><ref name="youtube"/><ref name="ah84">{{Cite news | last =Soutar | first =Paul | author-link = | publication-date =May 1984 | year =1984 | title =New Jersey's Big Guns | periodical =All Hands | series = | publication-place = | place =St. Alexandria, VA | publisher =United States Navy | volume = | issue =807 | pages =36â€“37 | url = | issn = | doi = | oclc = | postscript =<!--None-->}}</ref> The turrets were not actually attached to the ship, but sat on rollers, which meant that if the ship were to [[capsize]] the turrets would fall out.<ref>Underwater photos of the [[German battleship Bismarck|''Bismarck'']] show empty [[barbette]]s, vacated as the ship sank. John Asmussen. [http://www.bismarck-class.dk/bismarck/wreck/bismarck_wreck_5.html Bismarck - The Wreck - Part 5 - Aft & Rudder Area]. Accessed 2007-03-25</ref>Each turret cost US $1.4 million, but this number did not include the cost of the guns themselves.<ref name="Mark7"/>
The turrets were "three-gun," not "triple," because each barrel could be elevated and fired independently.<ref name="youtube"/> The ship could fire any combination of its guns, including a [[broadside]] of all nine.
The guns could be elevated from âˆ’5Â° to +45Â°, moving at up to 12Â° per second.<ref name="FAQ I"/> The turrets could be rotated about 300Â° at a rate of about four degrees per second and can even be fired back beyond the [[Beam (nautical)|beam]], which is sometimes called "over the shoulder."<ref name="FAQ I"/> The guns were never fired horizontally forward (in the 1980s refit, a satellite up-link antenna was mounted at the bow). To distinguish between the rounds fired from different battleships the ''Iowa'' class used dye bags which allowed artillery observers to determine which rounds had been fired by which ship. ''Iowa'', ''New Jersey'', ''Missouri,'' and ''Wisconsin'' were assigned the colors orange, blue, red and green, respectively.<ref name="Mark7"/>
Within each turret, a red stripe on the interior wall, inches from the railing, marked the boundary of the barrel's recoil, warning the crew to keep back.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ship/weaps/mk-7.htm |title=Mark 7 16-inch/50-caliber gun |accessdate=2007-03-12 |publisher=Federation of American Scientists| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070311085437/https://fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ship/weaps/mk-7.htm| archivedate= 11 March 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[Image:Iowa 16 inch Gun-EN.svg|thumb|right|Cut away of a {{convert|16|in|mm|0|adj=on}} gun turret]] When brought into service during World War II the guns had a barrel life of roughly 290 rounds, limited in large part by the nitrated cellulose (NC) propellant.<ref name="Mark7"/> After World War II the Navy switched to smokeless powder diphenylamine (SPD), a cooler-burning propellant, which increased the barrel life from 290 to about 350 rounds. This was increased further by the introduction of a titanium dioxide and wax compound known as "Swedish Additive" on {{USS|New Jersey|BB-62|2}} for her tour in Vietnam, and later used on all four ''Iowa''s when they were reactivated in the 1980s.<ref name="Mark7"/> These measures were further augmented by the addition of polyurethane jackets, which were placed over the powder bags to reduce gaseous erosion during the firing of the guns. These measures greatly prolonged barrel life, and ultimately resulted in a shift from measuring barrel life in equivalent service rounds (ESR) to measuring barrel life in fatigue equivalent rounds (FER).<ref name="Mark7"/>
After the guns were fired, each rifle barrel had to be cleaned. Unlike small caliber guns which can be field-stripped, the guns aboard an ''Iowa''-class battleship could not be disassembled, so the gunners mates assigned the job of cleaning the rifles required a full day or more to ensure that the barrels were correctly and adequately cleaned. To clean the rifles, a bore brush was lifted by two sailors and inserted into the gun barrel, where it was pulled through the rifle with the same equipment used to load the shells. Within the turret, crewmen checked to ensure that the breech fittings were properly cleaned and lubricated, while sailors outside the turret scraped off soot, and painted over flash burns left from the explosive expulsion of the 16-inch shells from the gun barrels.<ref name="ah84"/>
[[File:USS Iowa Fire Control Tower.jpg|left|thumb|upright|USS ''Iowa'''s Fire Control Tower under construction in 1942]]
===Fire control=== The early main battery fire control consisted of the Fire Control Tower,<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2">{{cite book|title =NAVAL ORDNANCE AND GUNNERY, VOLUME 2 FIRE CONTROL, NAVPERS 10798-A|publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel|date =1958|location =Washington 25, D.C.}}</ref> two Mark 38 Gun Fire Control Systems (GFCS),<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20A4">{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=20A4. Aloft gun directors}}</ref> and fire control equipment located in two of the three turrets.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20A6">{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=20A6. Turrets}}</ref> As modernized in the 1980s, each turret carried a DR-810 radar that measured the muzzle velocity of each gun, which made it easier to predict the velocity of succeeding shots. Together with the Mark 160 FCS and better propellant consistency, the improvements created the most accurate battleship-caliber guns ever made.<ref name="Mark7"/>
====Fire control tower==== The '''fire control tower''' (''pictured'') was the Gunnery Officer's heavily armored battle station, and it was accessible to the Captain's heavily armored battle station, the Battle Bridge.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2"/> It was equipped with periscopes poking through the armor, and control consoles showing the status of the ship's weapons (director bearings, turret bearings, gun's loaded status, Fire Control (FC) Radar displays, ...).<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2"/> With the radar's displays, the Gunnery Officer could determine what Spots (aim corrections) were needed by watching the fall of shot around the target.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=20G12. Spotting}}</ref>
====Mark 38 gun fire control system==== The major components of the '''Mk38 Gun Fire Control System''' (GFCS) were the Director, Plotting Room, and interconnecting data transmission equipment.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=20A2. System elements}}</ref> Two systems, forward and aft, were each complete and independent.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E1" >{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=20E1. Location}}</ref> Their plotting rooms were isolated to protect against battle damage propagating from one to the other.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E1"/>
=====Director===== [[Image:Mk38 Director.jpg|right|thumb|Mark 38 Director]]
The forward '''Mk38 Director''' (''pictured'') was situated on top of the fire control tower. The director was equipped with optical sights, optical Mark 45 Rangefinder<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20A4"/> (the long thin boxes sticking out each side), and a Mark 13 Fire Control Radar antenna (the rectangular shape sitting on top).<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20A4"/> The purpose of the director was to track the target's present bearing and range.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c19D1">{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=19D1. System elements}}</ref> This could be done optically by the men inside using the sights and Rangefinder, or electronically with the [[radar]]. (The FC radar was the preferred method.) The present position of the target was called the Line-Of-Sight (LOS),<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c19D1"/> and it was continuously sent down to the Mk 8 Rangekeeper in the plotting room by [[Synchro]] transmitters.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c19D1"/> Also, when not using the radar's display to determine Spots, the director was the optical spotting station.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2"/>
=====Plotting room===== [[Image:Iowa Class Main Battery Plot.jpg|left|thumb|USS Missouri's Main Plot, c1950]]
The forward main battery plotting room was located below the waterline and inside the armored belt.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20A5">{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=20A5. Plotting rooms}}</ref> It housed the forward system's Mark 8 Rangekeeper, Mark 41 Stable Vertical, Mk13 FC Radar controls and displays, [[Parallax]] Correctors, Fire Control Switchboard, battle telephone switchboard, battery status indicators, assistant Gunnery Officers, and Fire Control Technicians (FTs).<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20A5" />
[[Image:Mk8 Rangekeeper.jpg|right|thumb|Mark 8 Rangekeeper]]
The Mk8 Rangekeeper was an electromechanical [[analog computer]]<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E6">{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=20E6. Rangekeeper Mark 8}}</ref> whose function was to continuously calculate the gun's bearing and elevation, Line-Of-Fire (LOF), to hit a future position of the target.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E6"/> It did this by automatically receiving information from the director (LOS), the FC Radar (range), the ship's [[gyrocompass]] (true ship's course), the ship's [[Pitometer log]] (ship's speed), the Stable Vertical (ship's roll and pitch), and the ship's anemometer (relative wind speed and direction).<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E6"/> Also, before the surface action started, the FTs made manual inputs for the average initial velocity of the projectiles fired out of the battery's gun barrels, and air density.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E6"/> With all this information, the Rangekeeper calculated the relative motion between the ship and the target.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E6"/> It then could calculate an offset angle and change of range between the target's present position (LOS) and future position at the end of the projectile's time of flight. To this bearing and range offset, it added corrections for gravity, wind, [[Magnus Effect]] of the spinning projectile, earth's curvature, and [[coriolis effect]]. The result was the turret's bearing and elevation orders (LOF).<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E6" /> During the surface action, range and deflection Spots and target altitude (not zero during Gun Fire Support) were manually entered.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E6"/>
[[Image:Mk41 StableVertical.jpg|left|thumb|Mark 41 Stable Vertical]]
The Mk 41 Stable Vertical (also called Gun Director) was a vertical seeking gyroscope.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E2"/> Its function was to establish and maintain a stable earth vertical with its associated horizontal plane.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E2"/> With the horizontal plane established, the Mk 41 continuously measured the angles between the deck and the horizontal plane.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E2">{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=20E2. Gun Director Mark 41 Mod 0 (stable vertical)}}</ref> These deck angles were continuously transmitted to the Rangekeeper so that it could keep the guns correctly elevated as the ship rolled and pitched.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E2"/> Mounted waist high on its side were the battery's firing keys. (''see picture'')<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E2"/> The left key was the [[Salvo]] Signal Key, and it sounded the Salvo Buzzer in each of the turrets to warn the gun crews that the guns were about to fire.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E2"/> The center key (with bumps on its handle for tactile identification) was the Automatic Firing Key. When this key was held closed, the Mk 41 was enabled to automatically fire the guns whenever the ship's deck was parallel the horizontal plane.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E2"/> Also, if the sea state was such that the turrets' elevation power drives could not keep up with the ship's motion, the guns could be held at a fixed elevation, and the MK 41 could again automatically fire the guns as described.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E2"/> The right key was the Hand Firing Key. It bypassed the Mk 41, and fired the guns directly.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E2"/>
The Mk 13 FC Radar supplied present target range, and it showed the fall of shot around the target so the Gunnery Officer could correct the system's aim with range and deflection spots put into the Rangekeeper.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E9">{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=20E9. Radar equipment}}</ref> It could also automatically track the target by controlling the director's bearing power drive.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E9"/> Because of radar, Fire Control systems are able to track and fire at targets at a greater range and with increased accuracy during the day, night, or inclement weather. This was demonstrated in November 1942 when the battleship {{USS|Washington|BB-56|6}} engaged the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] [[battlecruiser]] [[Japanese battleship Kirishima|''Kirishima'']] at a range of {{convert|18500|yd|m|-2}} at night.<ref name="Kirishima">{{cite book | last = Mindell | first = David | title = Between Human and Machine | publisher = Johns Hopkins | year = 2002 | location = Baltimore | pages = 262â€“263 | isbn = 0-8018-8057-2 }}</ref> The engagement left ''Kirishima'' in flames, and she was ultimately scuttled by her crew.<ref name = "early">{{cite journal | author = A. Ben Clymer | title = The Mechanical Analog Computers of Hannibal Ford and William Newell | publisher = IEEE Annals of the History of Computing | volume = 15 |issue = 2 |year = 1993 | url = http://web.mit.edu/STS.035/www/PDFs/Newell.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2006-08-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060909064108/http://web.mit.edu/STS.035/www/PDFs/Newell.pdf| archivedate= 9 September 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> This capability gave the United States Navy a major advantage in World War II, as the Japanese did not develop radar or automated fire control to the level of the US Navy and were at a significant disadvantage.<ref name="Kirishima"/> See also [[Battle of Surigao Strait|The Battle of Surigao Strait (25 October 1944)]] during the WWII Leyte Gulf landings. [[Image:FC Switchboard.jpg|right|thumb|Fire Control Switchboard]]
The [[Parallax]] Correctors were needed because the turrets were located hundreds of feet from the director. There was one for each turret, and each had the turret/director distance manually set in. They automatically received Relative Target Bearing (bearing from own ship's bow), and Target Range. They corrected the bearing order for each turret so that all rounds fired in a salvo converged on the same point.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=19D3. Parallax}}</ref>
The Fire Control Switchboard configured the battery.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E10">{{Cite book|title=Naval Ordnance And Gunnery, Volume 2 Fire Control, NAVPERS 10798-A |publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel |year =1958|edition=1958 |location =Washington 25, D.C. |chapter=20E10. Main-battery switchboard}}</ref> With it, the Gunnery Officer could mix and match the three turrets to the two GFCSs. He could have the turrets all controlled by the forward system, all controlled by the aft system, or split the battery to shoot at two targets.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20E10"/>
The assistant Gunnery Officers and Fire Control Technicians operated the equipment, talked to the turrets and ship's command by [[sound-powered telephone]], and watched the Rangekeeper's dials and system status indicators for problems. If a problem arose, they could correct the problem, or reconfigure the system to mitigate its effect.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2"/>
====Turret fire control systems==== Turrets 2 & 3 had optical rangefinders and ballistics computers. <ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20A6" /> (The rangefinders are the boxes on the turret's rear corners). If in a surface action the GFCSs were damaged, the Turret Officer could turn the Auto-Local rotary switch to Local and continue the action using the turret's fire control equipment.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2c20A6" />
===Ammunition=== [[Image:16-in Battleship Ammunition.JPG|thumb|left|16-inch naval gunfire shells]] The large caliber guns were designed to fire two different 16-inch shells: an armor-piercing round for anti-ship and anti-structure work and a high explosive round designed for use against unarmored targets and shore bombardment. A third type of ammunition for delivering tactical nuclear warheads was developed subsequently.
The Mk. 8 APC (Armor-Piercing, Capped) shell weighed 2,700 lb (1225 kg) and was designed to penetrate the hardened steel armor carried by foreign battleships.<ref name="FAQ I"/>{{Unreliable source?|date=May 2010}} At 20,000 yards (18 km) the Mk. 8 could penetrate 20 inches (500 mm) of steel armor plate.<ref name="Ammo">William H. Garzke and Robert O. Dulin, Jr. ''Battleships: United States Battleships 1935â€“1992''</ref> At the same range, the Mk. 8 could penetrate 21 feet (6.4 m) of reinforced concrete.<ref name="Ammo"/>
For unarmored targets and shore bombardment, the 1,900 lb (862 kg) Mk. 13 HC (High-Capacityâ€”referring to the large bursting charge) shell was available.<ref name="Ammo"/> The Mk. 13 shell would create a [[impact crater|crater]] 50 feet (15 m) wide and 20 feet (6 m) deep upon impact and detonation, and could defoliate trees 400 yards (360 m) from the point of impact.<ref name="Ammo"/>
The final type of ammunition developed for the ''Iowa'' class were "[[W19 (nuclear artillery shell)|Katie]]" shells. These shells were born from the concept of [[mutual assured destruction|nuclear deterrence]] that had begun to shape the United States armed forces as the Cold War began. To compete with the [[United States Air Force|Air Force]] and the [[United States Army|Army]], which had developed nuclear bombs and nuclear shells for use on the battlefield, the US Navy began a top-secret program to develop Mk. 23 nuclear naval shells with an estimated yield of 15 to 20 kilotons.<ref name="Secret"/> These shells were designed to be launched from the best seaborne artillery platform available, which at the time were the four ships of the ''Iowa'' class. The shells entered development around 1953, and were reportedly ready by 1956; it is not known whether they were ever deployed on the ''Iowa''-class battleships because the US Navy does not confirm or deny the presence of nuclear weapons aboard its ships.<ref name="Secret">{{cite book |last=Yenne |first=Bill |title=Secret Weapons of the Cold War |year=2005 |publisher=Berkley Books |location=New York |isbn=0-425-20149-X |pages=132â€“133 |chapter=Mega Artillery }}</ref> In 1991 the US unilaterally withdrew its nuclear artillery shells from service, and Russia responded in kind in 1992. The US removed around 1,300 nuclear shells from Europe and reportedly dismantled its last shells by 2003.<ref name="Ammo"/>
<gallery> File:USS Iowa (BB-61) projectile hoisted to spanning tray.jpg|Loading shell, 1986. File:USS Iowa (BB-61) placing powder bags.jpg|Placing powder bags, 1986. File:USS Iowa (BB-61) ramming powder bags.jpg|Ramming powder bags, 1986. </gallery>
==Secondary battery== The secondary battery was a dual-purpose weapon system; it was designed to defend the ship from either surface or airborne threats. The original secondary battery consisted of 10 Mark 28, Mod 2 twin gun mounts,<ref name="NavWeaps">{{cite web |url=http://www.navweaps.com|title=Navy Weapons|accessdate=2007-08-07 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070814030550/http://www.navweaps.com/| archivedate= 14 August 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and four Mark 37 Gun Fire Control Systems.<ref name="FAS Iowa"/> At first, this battery's effectiveness against aircraft diminished as planes became faster, but this changed toward the end of [[World War II]] through a combination of an upgrade to the Mk37 System and the development of the VT (Variable Time) [[proximity fuze]]. In preparation for the reactivations in the 1960s and 1980s, the battery was updated to the latest gun and fire control system modifications. In the 1968 upgrade to the USS New Jersey for service off Vietnam, three Mark 56 Gun Fire Control Systems were installed, two on either side just forward of the aft stack, and one between the aft mast and the aft Mk 38 Director tower.<ref name="StfnTrzbWWIIBttleShip">{{cite book | last = Terzibaschitsch | first = Stefan |author2=Heinz O. Vetters|author3=Richard Cox | others = Siegfried Beyer | title = Battleships of the U.S. Navy in World War II | publisher = Bonanza Books | location = New York, New York | isbn = 0-517-23451-3 | pages = 147â€“153 | year = 1977 }}</ref> This increased New Jersey's anti-aircraft capability, because the Mk 56 system could track and shoot at faster planes. In the 1980s modernization, the Mk 56 GFCSs and four mounts were removed to make room for missiles, leaving the Secondary battery with four Mk 37 GFCSs and six twin mounts on all the ''Iowa'' class.<ref name="FAS Iowa"/> By the time of the [[Gulf War]] the secondary battery was largely relegated to shore bombardment and [[littoral]] defense.<ref name="FAQ I"/> Since each battleship carried a small detachment of [[United States Marine Corps|Marines]] aboard, the Marines would man one of the 5-inch gun mounts.<ref name="AH84N">{{Cite news | last =Wass | first =Becki | author-link = | publication-date =November 1984 | year =1984 | title =Iowa gets new Marine Guard Chief | periodical =All Hands | series = | publication-place =Alexandria, VA | place = | publisher =United States Navy | volume = | issue =813 | page =27 | url = | issn = | doi = | oclc = | postscript =<!--None-->}}</ref>
===Mark 28, Mod 2 mounts=== [[Image:5-inch 38-caliber cropped.jpg|thumb|right|A 5-inch (127 mm) gun mount emblazoned with the [[Eagle, Globe, and Anchor]] of the [[United States Marine Corps]] aboard the battleship {{USS|New Jersey|BB-62|2}}]]
[[Image:One of the 5" twin gun turrets on the USS Missouri.jpg|thumb|left|5-inch Gun aboard the Iowa-class battleship {{USS|Missouri|BB-63|2}}]]
Each '''Mk 28 Mod 2 Mount''' carried two [[5"/38 caliber gun|Mark 12, 5in/38cal gun assemblies]], electric-hydraulic drives for bearing and elevation, optical sights, automatic fuze setter, automatic sight setter, and an upper handling room. Each armored twin mount weighed {{convert|170635|lb|abbr=on}}.<ref name="NavWeaps"/> The mount had a crew of 13, not including the ammunition movers in the upper handling room and magazines, drawn from the sailors and Marines serving aboard the ship.
====Mark 12 gun assembly==== {{Further|5"/38 caliber gun}} [[Image:Mk12 5in Gun Assembly.jpg|left|thumb|Mk 12 Gun Assembly (right gun)]][[Image:5in38cal Semifixed Ammunition.JPG|right|thumb|5"/38cal semi-fixed ammunition. Anti-aircraft Common (AAC) Projectile with Full Service Charge.]]
The '''Mk12 Gun Assembly''' (''pictured'') was a semi-automatic, power rammed, vertical sliding-wedge breech block type gun. Since this gun assembly fired [[5"/38 caliber gun#Ammunition|semi-fixed ammunition]], (''pictured'') each round was delivered to the guns in two pieces.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV1"/> Each gun, in this twin mount, had its own projectile hoist and powder case hoist from the upper handling room. The electric-hydraulic projectile hoist would deliver a projectile next to the projectile man with the nose down and waist high. The electric-hydraulic powder case hoist poked the case through a powder scuttle in the gun room's deck just next to the powder man's feet.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV1"/> At the load command, the powder man would slip a primer protector off the end of the powder case, extract the case from the scuttle, and lift it into the gun's rammer tray. Meanwhile, the projectile man would pull a projectile out of the hoist, and place it in the rammer tray in front of the powder case. Then, as he turned to get the next projectile out of the hoist, the projectile man would pull down on the rammer lever. This caused the power rammer to ram the projectile and powder case into the chamber. As the powder case cleared the top of the breechblock, the block would rise to seal the chamber. The gun was ready to fire. The case combination primer in the base of the powder case could be fired either electrically or by percussion.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV1"/> Electrical firing was the preferred method because the firing circuit could be energized by firing keys down in the plotting room when firing salvos at surface targets, or up in the director when firing at air targets. Percussion firing could be executed by the Pointer (man controlling elevation) by pushing a foot treadle. When the gun fired, the recoil's rearward motion returned the rammer lever to the up position, and the rammer would drive back to the rear of the rammer tray. During counter-recoil, the breechblock was automatically lowered and the spent powder case was ejected from the chamber. When the gun returned to battery, a blast of compressed air was sent down the bore to clean it out. The gun was ready to be reloaded.
====Electric-hydraulic drives==== The electric-hydraulic drives powered the mount's motion. The three modes of drive operation were automatic, local, and manual. In automatic, the drives would follow the bearing and elevation orders of the fire control system. In local, the drives would follow the motion of the trainer's and pointer's hand wheels. (This is similar to power steering on a car.) Manual was direct gear linkage from the hand wheels to move the mount with no power assist.
====Sights==== The periscopic sights (the boxes on the side of the mount) allowed the trainer and pointer to see the target from inside the armored enclosure. Each sight had movable prisms that allowed its line of sight to be moved relative to the barrel's bore axis.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV1"/> These prisms could be controlled by the fire control system when the mount was in Automatic, or by the mount's sight setter operator when the mount was in Local. Local control was not the preferred combat method, but it could be used if the fire control systems were damaged. The mount captain was trained in aiming and correcting the fall of shot.
====Upper handling room==== The upper handling room was just below the visible part of the mount. It was armored<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV1">{{cite book |title =NAVAL ORDNANCE AND GUNNERY, VOLUME 1, NAVAL ORDNANCE, NAVPERS 10797-A|publisher =U.S. Navy, Bureau of Naval Personnel|date =1957|location =Washington 25, D.C.}}</ref> and reinforced to support the weight of the mount. A person standing in the upper handling room could look up and see the bottom of the gun mount inside the training circle on which the mount rotated. Hanging from the mount, and rotating with it, was the equipment used to pass ammunition up to the mount. This included the lower ends of the projectile and powder case hoists. In the center of the room there was a vertical tube that also turned with the mount. This tube enclosed the electrical power and control cables going up to the mount. Around the perimeter of the upper handling room were the ready service ammunition racks welded to the bulkheads. Close by, either in a corner of the handling room or in an adjoining compartment was the upper end of an ammunition hoist from the magazine. The responsibility of the men stationed in the upper handling room was to shuttle 30 to 40 projectiles and 30 to 40 powder cases per minute from the ready service racks to the hoists while avoiding the equipment rotating with the mount.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV1"/> During quiet spells, they would replenish the ready service racks with ammunition from the magazines.
===Mark 37 gun fire control system=== [[Image:Mk37 Director circa1944.jpg|right|thumb|Mk 37 Director c1944]] The [[Mark 37 Gun Fire Control System]] (GFCS) was the primary Fire Control System for the Secondary Battery. There were four Mk37 GFCSs on board; one forward above the navigation bridge, two amidships on either side of the forward stack, and one aft between the aft Mk38 Director and Turret three. The major components of the Mk 37 GFCS were the Mk 37 Director, and the equipment in the plotting room.
====Mark 37 director==== The function of the [[Mark 37 director]] (''pictured'') was to track the present position of the target in bearing, elevation, and range. To do this, it had optical sights (the rectangular widows on the front), an optical rangefinder (the tubes sticking out each side), and Fire Control Radar antennas. On the MK 37 Director pictured, the rectangular antenna is for the Mark 12 FC radar, and the parabolic antenna on the left is for the Mk 22 FC radar. They were part of an upgrade to improve tracking of aircraft.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2"/> The Director Officer also had a Slew Sight that he could use to quickly point the director towards a new target.
====Plotting room==== The secondary battery plotting rooms were down below the waterline and inside the armor belt. They contained four complete sets of fire control equipment needed to aim and shoot at four targets. Each set included a Mark 1A computer, a Mark 6 Stable Element, FC Radar controls and displays, Parallax correctors, a switchboard, and crew to operate it all.
[[File:Mark 1A Fire Control Computer Controls.jpg|left|thumb|Mark 1A Computer]] The [[Mark I Fire Control Computer|Mark 1A Fire Control Computer]] (''pictured'') was an electro-mechanical analog ballistic computer. Its function was to automatically aim the guns so that a fired projectile would collide with the target.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2"/> This was the same function as the main battery's Mk 8 Rangekeeper above except that some of the targets the Mark 1A had to deal with also moved in elevation â€” and much faster. For a surface target, the Secondary Battery's Fire Control problem is the same as the Main Battery's with the same type inputs and outputs. The major difference between the two computers was their ballistics calculations. The amount of gun elevation needed to project a 5-inch (127 mm) shell {{convert|9|nmi|km|abbr=on}} is different than the elevation needed to project a 16-inch shell the same distance. The ballistics calculations in these mechanical analog computers were performed by mechanisms like differential gears, levers, and small rods riding on the surface of three-dimensional cams. These mechanical adders, multipliers, and table lookup devices were handmade at the factory, and were buried deep in the workings of the computer. It was not possible to change a computer's ballistics at sea until the advent of fast digital computers. The anti-aircraft fire control problem was more complicated because it had the additional requirement of tracking the target in elevation and making target predictions in three dimensions. The outputs of the Mk 1A were the same (gun bearing and elevation), except fuze time was added. The fuze time was needed because the ideal of directly hitting the fast moving aircraft with the projectile was impractical. With fuze time set into the shell, it was hoped that it would explode near enough to the target to destroy it with the shock wave and shrapnel. Towards the end of [[World War II]], the invention of the VT [[proximity fuze]] eliminated the need to use the fuze time calculation and its possible error. This greatly increased the odds of destroying an air target.
[[Image:Mk6 Stable Element.jpg|right|thumb|Mark 6 Stable Element]] The function of the Mk 6 Stable Element (''pictured'') in this fire control system was the same as the function of the Mk 41 Stable Vertical in the main battery system above. It was a vertical seeking gyroscope that supplied the system with a stable up direction on a rolling and pitching ship. In surface mode, it replaced the director's elevation signal.<ref name="NavOrdAndGunV2"/> It also had the surface mode firing keys.
The [[Fire-control radar]] used on the Mk 37 GFCS has evolved. In the 1930s, the Mk 37 Director did not have a radar antenna. Then in September 1941,<ref>Naval Weapons of WW2, Campbell, p111.</ref> the rectangular Mk 4 Fire-control radar antenna was mounted on top. Soon aircraft flew faster, and in c1944 to increase speed and accuracy the Mk 4 was replaced by a combination of the Mk 12 (rectangular antenna) and Mk 22 (parabolic antenna) radars. (''pictured'')<ref name="NavWeaps"/> Finally, the circular SPG 25 antenna was mounted on top as seen in the USS Wisconsin photo at the top of this article. (Look at the Mk 37 Director just above the bridge.)
==Anti-aircraft batteries== [[Image:USS Iowa (BB-61) Oerlikon 20mm AA gun mount.jpg|thumb|left|An Oerlikon 20 mm anti-aircraft gun aboard the battleship {{USS|Iowa|BB-61|6}}.]] Since they were designed to escort the US fleet of fast attack aircraft carriers, the ''Iowa''-class battleships were all intended to carry a fearsome array of anti-aircraft guns to protect US aircraft carriers from Japanese fighters and dive bombers. This array included up to 20 quad 40 mm mounts and 49 single 20 mm mounts.<ref name="StfnTrzbWWIIBttleShip"/> In the 1968 USS New Jersey re-activation for service off Vietnam, the 20 mm and 40 mm batteries were removed.<ref name="StfnTrzbWWIIBttleShip"/> In the 1980s re-activation, all the ships with 20 mm and 40 mm batteries had them removed, and four Phalanx CIWS mounts were added to all.
===Oerlikon 20 mm anti-aircraft guns=== The [[Oerlikon Contraves|Oerlikon]] [[Oerlikon 20 mm cannon|20 mm anti-aircraft gun]] was one of the most heavily produced [[anti-aircraft gun]]s of the [[Second World War]]; the US alone manufactured a total of 124,735 of these guns. When activated in 1941 these guns replaced the [[M2 Browning machine gun|0.50"/90 (12.7 mm) M2 Browning MG]] on a one-for-one basis. The Oerlikon 20 mm AA gun remained the primary anti-aircraft weapon of the United States Navy until the introduction of the [[Bofors 40 mm gun|40 mm Bofors AA gun]] in 1943.<ref name="Oerlikon">{{cite web |url=http://www.navweaps.com/Weapons/WNUS_2cm-70_mk234.htm |title=United States of America 20 mm/70 (0.79") Marks 2, 3 & 4 |accessdate=2007-02-25 |date=September 2006 |author=DiGiulian, Tony |publisher = navweaps.com| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070225152339/http://www.navweaps.com/Weapons/WNUS_2cm-70_mk234.htm| archivedate= 25 February 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
These guns were air-cooled and used a gas blowback recoil system. Unlike other automatic guns employed during World War II the barrel of the 20 mm Oerlikon gun did not recoil, the breechblock never locked against the breech and actually moved forward when the gun fired. This weapon lacked a counter-recoil brake, as the force of the counter-recoil was checked by the explosion of the next round of ammunition.<ref name="Oerlikon"/>
[[Image:Bofors firing USS Hornet.jpg|thumb|right|Bofors 40 mm anti-aircraft guns on a MK 12 quadruple mount fire from the deck of the {{USS|Hornet|CV-12|6}} in World War II.]] Between December 1941 and September 1944, 32% of all Japanese aircraft downed were credited to this weapon, with the high point being 48.3% for the second half of 1942. In 1943 the revolutionary Mark 14 Gun Sight was introduced which made these guns even more effective; however, the 20 mm guns were found to be ineffective against the Japanese [[Kamikaze]] attacks used during the latter half of World War II. They were subsequently phased out in favor of the heavier [[Bofors 40 mm gun|40 mm Bofors AA gun]]s.<ref name="Oerlikon"/>
===Bofors 40 mm anti-aircraft guns=== [[Image:Mk51 Director.jpg|left|thumb|Mark 51 Director with Mark 14 (40 mm) Gun Sight]] Arguably the best light anti-aircraft weapon of World War II,<ref name="Bofors">{{cite web |url=http://www.navweaps.com/Weapons/WNUS_4cm-56_mk12.htm |title=United States of America 40 mm/56 (1.57") Mark 1, Mark 2 and M1 |accessdate=2007-02-25 |date=November 2006 |author=DiGiulian, Tony |publisher = navweaps.com| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070221160521/http://www.navweaps.com/Weapons/WNUS_4cm-56_mk12.htm| archivedate= 21 February 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> the [[Bofors 40 mm anti-aircraft gun]] was used on almost every major warship in the US and UK fleet during World War II from about 1943 to 1945.<ref name="Bofors"/> Although a descendant of German and Swedish designs, the Bofors mounts used by the US Navy during World War II had been heavily "Americanized" to bring the guns up to the standards placed on them by the US Navy. This resulted in a guns system set to English standards (now known as the [[United States customary units|Standard System]]) with interchangeable ammunition, which simplified the logistics situation for World War II. When coupled with electric-hydraulic drives for greater speed and the Mark 51 Director (''pictured'') for improved accuracy, the Bofors 40 mm gun became a fearsome adversary, accounting for roughly half of all Japanese aircraft shot down between 1 October 1944 and 1 February 1945.<ref name="Bofors"/>
When the ''Iowa''-class battleships were launched in 1943 and 1944 they carried twenty quad Bofors 40 mm gun mounts, which they used for defense against enemy aircraft. These heavy guns were also employed in the protection of allied aircraft carriers operating in the [[Asiatic-Pacific Theater|Pacific Theater of World War II]]. These guns remained on the battleships ''Iowa, Missouri,'' and ''Wisconsin'' from the time they were commissioned until they were reactivated for service in the 1980s.<ref>USS ''New Jersey'' had her 40 mm guns removed in 1968 when she was called into action for the Vietnam War. - [http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/n4/new_jersey-ii.htm Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships - New Jersey] Retrieved 30 March 2007</ref> As each battleship arrived for modernization during the early and mid-1980s the Bofors mounts that remained aboard were removed due in large part to the ineffectiveness of such manually aimed weapons against modern day jet fighters and enemy missiles. The replacement for the Bofors guns was the US Navy's [[Phalanx CIWS|Phalanx]] [[Close-in weapon system]] (CIWS).<ref name="FAS Iowa"/>
===Phalanx CIWS=== [[Image:Close-In Weapon System.jpg|thumb|right|A Phalanx CIWS mount aboard the [[amphibious assault ship]] {{USS|Kearsarge|LHD-3|6}}.]]
During their modernization in the 1980s, each ''Iowa''-class battleship was equipped with four of the US Navy's [[Phalanx CIWS]] mounts, two of which sat just behind the bridge and two which were forward and outboard of the after ship's funnel. {{USS|Iowa|BB-61|2}}, {{USS|New Jersey|BB-62|2}}, and {{USS|Missouri|BB-63|2}} were equipped with the Block 0 version of the Phalanx, while {{USS|Wisconsin|BB-64|2}} received the first operational Block 1 version in 1988.<ref name="navwiz">{{cite web |url= http://www.navweaps.com/Weapons/WNUS_Phalanx.htm |title=United States of America 20 mm Phalanx Close-in Weapon System (CIWS) |author=DiGiulian, Tony |date = 7 September 2006 | publisher = navweaps.com | accessdate=2007-03-14}}</ref>
Developed as the final line of defense (terminal defense or point defense) against anti-ship missiles, the Phalanx Close in Weapon System (CIWS, pronounced "''sea-whiz''") is the anti-aircraft/anti-missile gun currently in use in the US Navy. Due to their distinctive shape, they have been nicknamed "R2D2s", in reference to the droid [[R2-D2]] from the [[Star Wars]] universe.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://defensetech.org/2005/06/20/r2-d2-vs-mortar-rounds/ |title=Defense Tech: R2-D2 vs Mortar Rounds |author=Christian Lowe |accessdate=2007-03-21 |publisher=Defense Tech}}</ref> Designed in the early 1970s by [[General Dynamics]], and currently produced by [[Raytheon]], the Phalanx CIWS mount utilizes a 20 mm [[M61 Vulcan]] [[Gatling gun]] to destroy enemy missiles and aircraft that manage to escape anti-missile and anti-aircraft missiles fired from friendly ships.<ref name="gswiz">{{cite web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/ship/systems/mk-15.htm |title=MK 15 Phalanx Close-In Weapons System (CIWS) |accessdate=2007-03-14 |publisher=Global Security| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070315012243/http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/ship/systems/mk-15.htm| archivedate= 15 March 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The Phalanx guns worked by using a search radar and a tracking radar to follow targets that approached within 1 to {{convert|1.5|nmi|km|1}}.<ref name="gswiz"/><!--conflicting reports, please confirm!--> When a target was within this range the CIWS mount moved to track the target while simultaneously evaluating the target against several preset criteria to determine the next course of action. Depending on whether the target criteria were met, the Phalanx mount automatically engaged the incoming target if it was judged to be hostile in nature, or the system recommended that the Phalanx operator engage the target.<ref name="gswiz"/>
Phalanx CIWS mounts were used by ''Missouri'' and ''Wisconsin'' during the 1991 [[Gulf War]]; ''Wisconsin'' alone fired 5,200 20 mm Phalanx CIWS rounds.<ref name="USS Wisconsin">{{cite web | title = The USS Wisconsin (BB-64) Ship's History | url = http://www.usswisconsin.org/General/Ships%20History.htm |publisher= USS Wisconsin Association |accessdate=2006-11-26}}</ref> ''Missouri'' also received Phalanx fire during a "[[friendly fire]]" incident in which the {{sclass-|Oliver Hazard Perry|frigate|0}} [[guided missile frigate]] {{USS|Jarrett|FFG-33|6}} mistook [[Chaff (radar countermeasure)|chaff]] fired by ''Missouri'' for a legitimate target and shot at ''Missouri''. Rounds from this attack struck the ship in the bulkhead above the famed "surrender deck" and bounced off the armor, one round penetrated the forward funnel and passed completely through it, and another round penetrated a bulkhead and embedded in an interior passageway of the ship.<ref name="friendly fire I">{{cite web |url=http://www.gulflink.osd.mil/du_ii/du_ii_tabh.htm |title=TAB H -- Friendly-fire Incidents |accessdate=2007-02-25 |last=Rostker |first=Bernard |date=December 2000 |work=Depleted Uranium in the Gulf (II) |publisher=United States Department of Defense| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070207054642/http://www.gulflink.osd.mil/du_ii/du_ii_tabh.htm| archivedate= 7 February 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Missiles== During the modernization in the 1980s, three important weapons were added to the ''Iowa''-class battleships. The first was the CIWS anti-aircraft/anti-missile system discussed above. The other two were missiles for use against both land and sea targets. At one point the NATO [[Sea Sparrow]] was to be installed on the reactivated battleships; however, it was determined that the system could not withstand the over-pressure effects when the main battery was fired.<ref>Statement by Admiral Rowden in the ''Department of Defense Appropriations for Fiscal Year 1982''. {{OCLC|11640298}}.</ref>
===Tomahawk land attack missile=== [[Image:USSNewJersey tomohawk.jpg|thumb|left|An Armored Box Launcher equipped on the battleship {{USS|New Jersey|BB-62|6}}.]] The [[BGM-109 Tomahawk|BGM-109 Tomahawk Land Attack Missile]] (TLAM) was first introduced in the 1970s, and entered service with the United States in 1983. Designed as a long-range, all-weather, subsonic [[cruise missile]], the Tomahawk was capable of reaching targets at a much greater range than the {{convert|16|in|mm|0|adj=on}} guns on the ''Iowa''-class ships. When added to the battleships in the 1980s the Tomahawk became the longest-ranged weapon carried by the battleships.<ref>The maximum range for the Tomahawk Land Attack Missile is {{convert|675|nmi|km|abbr=on}}, the maximum range for the Harpoon was {{convert|85|nmi|km|abbr=on}}, ([https://web.archive.org/web/20090129155040/http://www.battleship.org/html/Articles/IowaClass/Missile.htm Iowa Class: Missile Battery.] battleship.org, Retrieved on 2007-03-25) and the maximum range for the {{convert|16|in|mm|0|adj=on}} guns was {{convert|24|nmi|km|abbr=on}}.([https://web.archive.org/web/20060531135341/http://www.factplace.com/mightymo.htm#Weps USS Missouri (BB-63)FAQ.] factplace.com, Retrieved on 2007-03-25)</ref>
Owing to the original 1938 design of the battleships, the Tomahawk missiles could not be fitted to the ''Iowa''-class unless the battleships were physically rebuilt in such a way as to accommodate the missile mounts that would be needed to store and launch the Tomahawks. This realization prompted the removal of the anti-aircraft guns previously installed on the ''Iowas'' and the removal of four of each of the battleships' ten 5"/38 DP mounts. The mid and aft end of the battleships were then rebuilt to accommodate the missile magazines. This resulted in the construction of two separate platforms, one located between the first and second funnel and one located behind the second funnel, to which MK-143 [[Armored Box Launcher]] (ABL) canisters could be attached. Each Armored Box Launcher carried four missiles, and each of the battleships was outfitted with eight canisters, enabling the ''Iowa''-class to carry and fire a total of 32 Tomahawk missiles.<ref name="FAS Iowa">{{cite web | title = BB-61 IOWA-class (Specifications) | url = https://fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ship/bb-61.htm |publisher=[[Federation of American Scientists]] |accessdate=2006-11-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061125043334/https://fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ship/bb-61.htm| archivedate= 25 November 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The type of Tomahawk carried by the battleships varied, as there were three basic configurations for the Tomahawk: the Anti-Ship Missile (TASM), the Land-Attack Missile-Conventional (TLAM-C), and the Land-Attack Missile-Nuclear (TLAM-N). Each version was similar in appearance and used the same airframe body and launcher.<ref name="missile system">{{cite web |url=http://www.battleship.org/html/Articles/IowaClass/Missile.htm |title=Iowa Class: Missile Battery | accessdate=2007-03-06 |publisher=Iowa class preservation society|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129155040/http://www.battleship.org/html/Articles/IowaClass/Missile.htm|archivedate=2009-01-29}}</ref> The conventional Tomahawk missile could carry a {{convert|1000|lb|abbr=on}} explosive warhead or [[submunition]]s which used the missile body to reach their destination. The nuclear variant carried a 200 [[Kilotons of TNT|kt]] [[W80 (nuclear warhead)|W80]] [[nuclear warhead]].<ref name="FAS Tomahawk">{{cite web |url=https://fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/smart/bgm-109.htm |title=BGM-109 Tomahawk |accessdate=2007-03-18 |author=Federation of American Scientists| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070314230807/https://fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/smart/bgm-109.htm| archivedate= 14 March 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The TLAM could be equipped with an inertial and terrain contour matching ([[TERCOM]]) radar guidance package to find and destroy its target. The TERCOM radar used a stored map reference to compare with the actual terrain to determine the missile's position. If necessary, a course correction was then made to place the missile on course to the target. Terminal guidance in the target area was provided by the optical Digital Scene Matching Area Correlation (DSMAC) system, which compared a stored image of target with the actual target image.<ref name="FAS Tomahawk"/>
The firing weight of the Tomahawk was {{convert|2650|lb|abbr=on}} plus a {{convert|550|lb|abbr=on}} booster. It had a cruising speed of 0.5 Mach and an attack speed of 0.75 Mach. The anti-ship version of the Tomahawk had an operating range of {{convert|250|nmi|km|abbr=on}} and a maximum range of {{convert|470|nmi|km|abbr=on}}, while the conventional land attack missile version had a maximum range of {{convert|675|nmi|km|abbr=on}} and TLAM-N had maximum range of {{convert|1500|nmi|km|abbr=on}}.<ref name="missile system"/>
During the 1991 [[Gulf War]], USS ''Missouri'' and USS ''Wisconsin'' used ABL launchers to fire Tomahawk missiles at Iraqi targets during Operation Desert Storm. ''Wisconsin'' served as the Tomahawk Land Attack Missile (TLAM) strike commander for the Persian Gulf, directing the sequence of launches that marked the opening of Operation Desert Storm and fired a total of 24 of her own TLAMs during the first two days of the campaign.<ref name="Desert Storm">{{cite web|title = V: "Thunder And Lightning"- The War With Iraq (Subsection:The War At Sea) |work= The United States Navy in "Desert Shield" / "Desert Storm"| url = http://www.history.navy.mil/wars/dstorm/ds5.htm |publisher= [[United States Navy]] |accessdate=2006-11-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061205022732/http://history.navy.mil/wars/dstorm/ds5.htm| archivedate= 5 December 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Harpoon anti-ship missile=== [[Image:Mk 141 Harpoon Missile Launcher.JPG|thumb|right|An Mk 141 Quad cell Launcher aboard the German frigate ''Bremen'']] For protection against enemy ships, the ''Iowa'' class was outfitted with the Harpoon Weapons System. The system consisted of four Mk 141 "shock-hardened" quad cell launchers designed to carry and fire the [[McDonnell Douglas]]<!--Boeing didn't buy MD until long after the Iowas were mothballed --> [[Boeing Harpoon|RGM-84 Harpoon]] anti-ship missile. Each Harpoon was placed in one of four Mk 141 launchers located alongside the aft [[Funnel (ship)|stack]]; eight per side, in two pods of four. The weight of the Harpoon at firing was {{convert|1530|lb|abbr=on}}, which included a booster weighing about {{convert|362|lb|abbr=on}}. The cruising speed was 0.87 Mach and the maximum range was {{convert|64|nmi|km|abbr=on}} in Range and Bearing Launch mode and {{convert|85|nmi|km|abbr=on}} in Bearing Only Launch mode.<ref name="missile system"/>
When an ''Iowa'' class battleship fired a Harpoon Missile, a booster propelled the missile away from the ship; after approximately {{convert|5|mi|km|0}}, the booster dropped away. After the booster was discarded a turbojet engine ignited and propelled the missile to the target. The stabilizing and actuator fins, which helped to guide the missile to its target, were stored folded in the canister and sprang into position after launching. These fins directed the missile to the target through inputs from the AN/SWG-1 Harpoon Fire Control System.<ref name="missile system"/>
The battleships carried and used the RGM/UGM-84 variants of the Harpoon Missile, which was designed to be fired by surface ships. The version used a solid-fueled rocket booster in an A/B44G-2 or -3 booster section, which was discarded after burn-out. The maximum range was around {{convert|140|km|nmi}}.<ref name="Harpoon missile">{{cite web |url= http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/harpoon.htm | title= Boeing (McDonnell-Douglas) AGM/RGM/UGM-84 Harpoon | accessdate=2007-03-06 |last=Parsch |first=Andreas | publisher = Encyclopedia Astronautica BLOG!| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061018165957/http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/harpoon.htm| archivedate = October 18, 2006}}</ref>
After launch, the missile was guided towards the target location as determined by the ship using a three-axis Attitude Reference Assembly (ATA) in an AN/DSQ-44 guidance section. The ATA was less accurate than a full-fledged inertial system, but good enough for Harpoon's range.<ref name="Harpoon missile"/> For stabilization and control, the AGM-84A had four fixed cruciform wings (3x BSU-42/B, 1x BSU-43/B) and four movable BSU-44/B tail fins. The missile flew at a low cruise altitude and at a predetermined distance from the expected target position, its AN/DSQ-28 J-band active radar seeker in the nose was activated to acquire and lock on the target. The radar switch-on distance could be set to lower or higher values, the former requiring a more precisely-known target location but reducing the risk to be defeated by enemy [[Electronic Counter Measures]] (ECM).<ref name="Harpoon missile"/>
An alternative launch mode was called Bearing-Only Launch (BOL). In this mode, the missile was launched in the general direction of the target, and its radar activated from the beginning to scan for the target in a +/- 45Â° sector in front of the flight path. Once a target was located and the seeker locked the xGM-84A missile climbed rapidly to about 1800 m before diving on the target in what was known as a "pop-up maneuver". The 221 kg (488 lb) WDU-18/B penetrating blast-fragmentation warhead (in the WAU-3(V) /B warhead section) was triggered by a time-delayed impact fuze.<ref name="Harpoon missile"/> When no target was acquired after radar activation, the Harpoon would self-destruct.<ref name="Harpoon missile"/>
